intro: Verbascum hookerianum var. ballii, commonly known as the Hooker's mullein, is a perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It is characterized by its tall, hairy stems and large, heart-shaped leaves that are covered in soft, downy hairs. The plant produces showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often growing in alpine or rocky habitats. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
